title: Michelsen avenges Norrie loss, claims 50th tour-level win in Delray Beach
description: How much things can change in a week! Alex Michelsen will be saying that after ousting former champion Cameron Norrie 7-6(3), 7-5 at the Delray Beach Open on Friday, avenging last week‚Äôs Dallas loss to the Briton. The American fought off a second-set scare, facing three consecutive set points on serve at 4-5. Yet in those key moments, the California native stayed ahead in rallies and used sharp angles with his backhand, forcing Norrie to hit from an uncomfortable range. ‚ÄúI told myself, 'Find a couple of first serves, you haven‚Äôt been broken the entire match, so why start now?‚Äô‚Äù Michelsen reflected on his 0/40 hold late in the second set. ‚ÄúI played a couple great points to get out of it and then I got very fortunate to get that break point at 5-5 and then played a great game at 6-5. Lucky to get out of that second set.‚Äù Michelsen then broke Norrie‚Äôs serve at 5-5 in the second set with a stroke of luck ‚Äî the American hit a backhand that dribbled over the net cord on break point, allowing him to serve for the match. The third seed avoided repeat drama in his ensuing service game, closing the one-hour, 38-minute match.The smile says it all üòÅ[3] Alex Michelsen reaches the Final Four 7-6(3) 7-5 past Norrie @DelrayBeachOpen | #DBOpen pic.twitter.com/26RltAVaUO‚Äî ATP Tour (@atptour) February 14, 2025 Last week, Norrie beat Michelsen 2-6, 7-6(1), 6-1 at the indoor ATP 500 in Dallas. Michelsen‚Äôs 32 winners in Florida were too much for the lefty to overcome. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs tough to play someone twice in two weeks,‚Äù Michelsen said. ‚ÄúI think Cam is a great player, a great competitor. His backhand is world class, I tried to stay away from that as much as I could. I didn‚Äôt do that amazing last time I played him, but this time I made some adjustments and the game plan worked well.‚Äù By advancing to his fifth tour-level semi-final, the 20-year-old secured his 50th tour-level match win, joining Delray Beach top seed and World No. 4 Taylor Fritz as the only active American men to record 50 victories before turning 21. Michelsen is up to No. 33 in the PIF ATP Live Rankings, three spots ahead of his career high. Michelsen, who is also in the doubles semis alongside Mackenzie McDonald, will next meet seventh seed Miomir Kecmanovic, who dismissed fifth seed Marcos Giron 2-6, 6-4, 6-2.‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt easy, but I tried to stay aggressive, try to go for even bigger shots and luckily it paid off,‚Äù said Kecmanovic, who earned his 100th tour-level hard-court win, becoming the fourth Serbian man in the Open Era to achieve that feat. Kecmanovic improved to 2-0 against Giron in their Lexus ATP Head2Head series and coincidentally, both wins came in the Delray Beach quarter-final stage (2023, 2025).[NEWSLETTER FORM]
excerpt: Alex Michelsen ousted former champion Cameron Norrie 7-6(3), 7-5 at the Delray Beach Open on Friday, avenging last week‚Äôs Dallas loss to the Briton. The American earned his 50th tour-level match win.

html:
Delray Beach

Michelsen avenges Norrie loss, claims 50th tour-level win in Delray Beach

The 20-year-old joins Fritz in slice of American history

February 14, 2025

delraybeachopen

Alex Michelsen saves three set points in the second set to avoid a decider against Cameron Norrie. By ATP Staff

How much things can change in a week!

Alex Michelsen will be saying that after ousting former champion Cameron Norrie 7-6(3), 7-5 at the Delray Beach Open on Friday, avenging last week‚Äôs Dallas loss to the Briton.

The American fought off a second-set scare, facing three consecutive set points on serve at 4-5. Yet in those key moments, the California native stayed ahead in rallies and used sharp angles with his backhand, forcing Norrie to hit from an uncomfortable range.

‚ÄúI told myself, 'Find a couple of first serves, you haven‚Äôt been broken the entire match, so why start now?‚Äô‚Äù Michelsen reflected on his 0/40 hold late in the second set. ‚ÄúI played a couple great points to get out of it and then I got very fortunate to get that break point at 5-5 and then played a great game at 6-5. Lucky to get out of that second set.‚Äù

Michelsen then broke Norrie‚Äôs serve at 5-5 in the second set with a stroke of luck ‚Äî the American hit a backhand that dribbled over the net cord on break point, allowing him to serve for the match. The third seed avoided repeat drama in his ensuing service game, closing the one-hour, 38-minute match.

‚Äî ATP Tour (@atptour) February 14, 2025

Last week, Norrie beat Michelsen 2-6, 7-6(1), 6-1 at the indoor ATP 500 in Dallas. Michelsen‚Äôs 32 winners in Florida were too much for the lefty to overcome.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs tough to play someone twice in two weeks,‚Äù Michelsen said. ‚ÄúI think Cam is a great player, a great competitor. His backhand is world class, I tried to stay away from that as much as I could. I didn‚Äôt do that amazing last time I played him, but this time I made some adjustments and the game plan worked well.‚Äù

By advancing to his fifth tour-level semi-final, the 20-year-old secured his 50th tour-level match win, joining Delray Beach top seed and World No. 4 Taylor Fritz as the only active American men to record 50 victories before turning 21. Michelsen is up to No. 33 in the PIF ATP Live Rankings, three spots ahead of his career high.

Michelsen, who is also in the doubles semis alongside Mackenzie McDonald, will next meet seventh seed Miomir Kecmanovic, who dismissed fifth seed Marcos Giron 2-6, 6-4, 6-2.

‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt easy, but I tried to stay aggressive, try to go for even bigger shots and luckily it paid off,‚Äù said Kecmanovic, who earned his 100th tour-level hard-court win, becoming the fourth Serbian man in the Open Era to achieve that feat.

Kecmanovic improved to 2-0 against Giron in their Lexus ATP Head2Head series and coincidentally, both wins came in the Delray Beach quarter-final stage (2023, 2025).
